title: 113_hr4786
content: The "Social Security Commission Act of 2014" establishes the "Commission on Long Term Social Security Solvency" to provide recommendations and proposed legislation for achieving solvency in the Federal Old-Age and Survivors Insurance Trust Fund and the Federal Disability Insurance Trust Fund for at least 75 years. The Commission's special message must be approved by at least 9 members. The Commission on Long Term Social Security Solvency consists of 13 members appointed by various officials, with specific qualifications for Congressional appointees. Appointments must be made within 45 days of the Act's enactment. The Commission on Long Term Social Security Solvency consists of 13 members appointed within 45 days of the Act's enactment. Members serve for the life of the Commission without pay but receive travel expenses. Vacancies are filled in the same manner as the original appointment. The Commission on Long Term Social Security Solvency has 13 members appointed within 45 days of the Act's enactment. Members serve for the life of the Commission without pay but receive travel expenses. Vacancies are filled in the same manner as the original appointment. The Commission operates and has powers outlined in Section 5. The Commission on Long Term Social Security Solvency appoints a Chair and Co-Chair, who establish rules of procedure and may hold hearings as needed. The Commission on Long Term Social Security Solvency can obtain official data from US departments, agencies, and organizations, and may also use contract authority to compensate for necessary services. Additionally, the Commission is allowed to use the United States mails for communication purposes. SEC. 6. PERSONNEL. The Commission shall have a Director appointed by the Commission, paid at a rate equivalent to a comparable position under the Executive Schedule. The Director may appoint additional staff and procure temporary services. Federal agencies may detail personnel to the Commission upon request. The Commission may receive administrative support services from the Administrator of General Services on a reimbursable basis. It can also accept gifts, bequests, or devises of services or property to aid its work, with money and proceeds deposited in the Treasury for disbursement upon the Commission's order. The Commission will terminate within 60 days of submitting the report. An authorization of up to $2,000,000 is provided for this Act. Commission recommendations will receive expedited consideration. Expedited consideration is given to approval bills introduced in each House after receiving a special message. The House of Representatives must report the bill without amendment within three legislative days of its introduction. Concurrent resolution provides for adjournment sine die at the end of a Congress, automatically discharging committees from further consideration of the bill. It will be placed on the appropriate calendar. Within 3 legislative days of the bill's approval or discharge from committee, a motion can be made to proceed to consider the bill in the House. The motion must be made within two legislative days after the proponent announces their intention to offer it. The proponent announces intention to offer a motion after approval bill is reported or committee discharged. Motion not allowed after House disposes of a similar motion. If motion to proceed is agreed, House immediately considers approval bill without delay. The approval bill is considered as read, with all points of order waived. The previous question is ordered on the approval bill for passage with limited debate. In the Senate, the appropriate committee must report the approval bill without amendment within three days of introduction. If a committee fails to report the approval bill within the specified period or if the Senate adjourns sine die, the Committee will be automatically discharged from further consideration. A motion to proceed to consider the approval bill in the Senate can be made by any Senator within 3 session days after the bill is reported or the committee is discharged. The motion will be decided without debate. If a motion to proceed to the consideration of the approval bill is agreed to, the Senate shall immediately proceed to consideration without any intervening motion or business. The approval bill will remain the unfinished business of the Senate until disposed of, with consideration not exceeding 10 hours. All points of order against the approval bill are waived, and consideration in the Senate is limited to 1 hour for any debatable motion or appeal. No amendments or motions to strike provisions are allowed for approval bills in both the Senate and the House of Representatives. Coordination with the other house is required for actions on approval bills. Coordination with the other house is required for actions on approval bills in the House of Representatives. If one House receives a bill from the other before passing the approval bill, the received bill will supplant the approval bill in the receiving House during the vote on passage. This rule does not apply to the House of Representatives. The approval bill described in subsection (c) must consist of proposed legislation to carry out recommendations made by the Commission on Long Term Social Security Solvency. If an approval bill is pending at the end of a Congress, it must be transmitted to the next Congress within the first 3 days of session. The Commission must transmit all information in a special message to Congress at the start of the next session. An approval bill can be introduced within the first five days of the session and will be treated as such under this section. Time periods for approval shall begin on the day of introduction of the bill.
